column4: I tried #linux, but they dont know... How do I open a folder for browsing in the terminal? *in windows this is start .*
there is "gnome-open"
is this distro language, or linux language. because my code has to work on all linux distros.
if you want to be specific you can also try things like "nautilus" or "thunar"
afaik gnome-open would work if gnome is installed and running.. there's probably something else for KDE or xfce
and gnome is pretty much always there, right? or only on ubuntu?
if you're writing an app that has to open a file browsing window I would suggest making this command configurable.. that way distro's can change it to whatever they want for their packages
Gnome is pretty big.. but so is KDE .. I doubt any desktop enviroment has over 50%
Problem is, i'm working on the php version atm. So it has to be done using command line tool...
is there a command to ask linux what's installed? that way I can use the terminal what to use. :)
there might very well be.. but I don't know it.. it would make sense to have an enviroment variable or similar
well, if i knew what was being used, gnome or kde *what else is there?* i can decide what set of commands to use for the app. it will work on windows, and all distro's of linux

well.. *all* linux distros will be very very hard..  there are linux distros running on small embedded systems.. without any displays at all, with gnome/KDE/xfce/other weird desktop enviroments.. some can use more than one file manager
I think you might want to aim for "most regular desktop" linux systems.. with KDE/Gnome/xfce you'll probably cover 80% or more.. those last percentages will take lots more work
yes. I will. people may request others if they like. but the only problem is, where do i find the system used, and the command for each of these systems. e.g. kde, gnome etc.
as Azelphur suggested.. the lsb modules might be a way.. searching a process list might tell you if gnome/KDE is running.. there might be other ways too
note that just because you run a certain distro doesn't mean you use the default desktop enviroment.. but it might be a pretty good starting guess
xkill, pkill, kill
how?
better even, where? it's running in UI not terminal.
xkill lets you click on a window you want to kill, pkill someprocess  will kill all processes named "someprocess", kil <pid> will kill the process with the process id <pid>
why not try rebooting..see if it comes back
